Expectation1: Ensure the safe and punctual operation of the subway train.
Situation1: A minor signal delay up ahead requires careful speed adjustments to maintain the schedule without causing abrupt movements.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: The train hums beneath my feet as I scan the control panel, eyes flicking to the signal indicator flashing yellow. There’s a delay up ahead—nothing major, but enough to demand my full attention. I adjust the speed, careful not to jolt the passengers. My radio crackles, but it’s my phone that vibrates insistently in my pocket. I glance down: a message from my activist group. The legislative aide I’ve been trying to reach for weeks is available to talk—right now, for the next ten minutes only. My heart pounds. I know how crucial this call is; it could tip the scales for the bill we’ve poured months into. But I’m responsible for hundreds of lives at this moment, expected to keep the train safe and on time. My mind races, torn between the duty to my passengers and the cause I believe in. The seconds tick by, each one tightening the knot in my chest as I weigh the demands of both worlds, knowing I can’t give my all to both at once.
